This is will sound strange and it does, couples on my counseling couch look back at me with wide eyes and in disbelief.

But I think one of the biggest protectors of fidelity in a long-term relationship, and particularly in a marriage, is to make sure that both of the partners have really strong, very intimate same-sex friendships.

A lot of times we make demands of each other in marriage relationship or in long-term relationship, and we pressure each other to provide for us what you really ought to be getting in friendship with somebody else.
And so one of the worst things to predict marital stability is I ask all the time couples in pre-marital, how close are your same-sex friends?
Because if you don't have intimate same-sex relationships or friendships, you're going to be demanding of your mate something that they won't have the capacity to always provide.
And when you come up feeling deprived, it is then that we're tempted to be unfaithful.

I found this even in very religious countries - in places like Indonesia where, you know, it's a predominantly Muslim country - that peer pressure seemed to be the most important factor, in fact, in creating a sexual culture where cheating is considered permissible.
